review.title: Event Search and Analytics: Detecting Events in Semantically Annotated Corpora for Search and Analytics
review.abstract: In this article, I present the questions that I seek to answer in my PhD research. I posit to analyze natural language text with the help of semantic annotations and mine important events for navigating large text corpora. Semantic annotations such as named entities, geographic locations, and temporal expressions can help us mine events from the given corpora. These events thus provide us with useful means to discover the locked knowledge in them. I pose three problems that can help unlock this knowledge vault in semantically annotated text corpora: i. identifying important events; ii. semantic search; and iii. event analytics.

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this article, I outlined the research I intend to undertake for my doctoral thesis, which, at its peak, would provide us with methods for computational extraction of world history as a sequence of chronological events and for depicting future events to take place from semantically annotated corpora. Research would also provide pathways for semantic search and large-scale event analysis of these annotated corpora. I also described already available resources that can be used to conduct research; test cases that can be built from encyclopedic resources on the Internet; and the metrics that can be used for evaluation.
